content.title: Drug-Eluting Stents in Peripheral Vascular Disease
content.description: Stents coated with antiproliferative drugs to reduce neointimal hyperplasia and in-stent restenosis, primarily used in femoropopliteal intervention.

drug_types.paclitaxel: Microtubule stabilizer, most common in peripheral
drug_types.sirolimus: mTOR inhibitor, more common in coronary

content.mechanism: Drug inhibits smooth muscle cell proliferation, reducing neointimal hyperplasia that causes restenosis

clinical_data.ZILVER_PTX: Landmark trial showing improved patency vs bare metal in SFA
clinical_data.comparison: Superior primary patency at 12-24 months vs bare metal

content.related_technology: Drug-coated balloons provide similar drug delivery without permanent implant
content.statement: Drug-Eluting Stents in Peripheral Vascular Disease is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Procedures Stent that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Drug-Eluting Stents in Peripheral Vascular Disease helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Drug-Eluting Stents in Peripheral Vascular Disease include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Drug-Eluting Stents in Peripheral Vascular Disease.
